title: Metabolic Effects of Fructose
content: Research into the causes of blood pressure resulted in a change of research direction to focus more on how fructose has such profound metabolic effects. The relationship between salt and high blood pressure, then provides a masterclass into uric acid, and then expertly reveals the mechanisms and pathways by which sugar (specifically fructose) can profoundly impact metabolic health. From there, he explains how he applies this information to real life patients as well as touches on some of the most promising ideas around pharmacotherapy that are being developed in response to the epidemics of fatty liver, insulin resistance, diabetes, and obesity. Furthermore, artificial sweeteners compared to real sugar, discusses cancer’s affinity for fructose.

title: Fructose and Health
content: The connection between blood pressure and fructose that shifted professional focus. The relationship between salt and blood pressure (and the role of sugar). Defining fructose, glucose, and sugar. An ancient mutation in apes that explains why humans turn fructose into fat so easily. The problems with elevated uric acid levels, and what it tells us about how sugar causes disease. How sugar causes obesity—explaining the difference in glucose vs. fructose metabolism and the critical pathway induced by fructose. Why drinking sugar is worse than eating it. Unique ability of sugar to drive oxidative stress to the mitochondria, insulin resistance, and diabetes. Why cancer loves fructose. The many areas of the body that can use fructose. Fructokinase inhibitors—a potential blockbuster? Treating high uric acid levels—approach with patients. Salt intake—what advice is given to patients? How excess glucose (i.e., high carb diets) can cause problems even in the absence of fructose. Artificial sweeteners vs. real sugar—which is better? Umami, MSG, alcohol, beer—do these have a role in metabolic illness? Fructose consumption—Is any amount acceptable? Is fruit okay? Where does one draw a hard line? How does one manage the sugar intake of young kids?

title: Insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting
content: Scientist with expertise in the areas of aging, cancer, and nutrition who translates complex scientific topics into actionable insights. Provides latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's.

title: Insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting
content: Latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more. Relationship between cancer and exercise as well as the link between alcohol consumption and cancer. New focus on exercise and protein consumption as well as how perspective has shifted as it pertains to fasting and time-restricted feeding.

title: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies
content: Discussion on Alzheimer’s disease risk factors, prevention strategies, and the role of APOE in brain health.

title: Training principles for longevity
content: Discussion on training principles that can contribute to longevity.

title: Preventing cardiovascular disease: diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health
content: Latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more for preventing cardiovascular disease.

title: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent
content: Discussion on the pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: The connection between blood pressure and fructose
content: Research into the cause of high blood pressure and the role of fructose in raising uric acid, which leads to high blood pressure.

title: The relationship between salt and blood pressure
content: Discussion on the relationship between salt and blood pressure, and the role of sugar. Drinking water with a salty meal can prevent a rise in blood pressure.

title: Inflammation and Autoimmune response to heat-shock proteins
content: Inflammation in the kidney can be a mechanism for triggering persistent elevations in blood pressure. An autoimmune reaction to heat shock proteins can also lead to high blood pressure.

title: Exercise and Health
content: You should NOT stop exercising because the net effect of exercise is still going too far outweigh the potential downside.

title: Role of Inflammation in Hypertension
content: One of the big breakthroughs has been the discovery that inflammation in the kidney can be a mechanism for triggering persistent elevations in blood pressure and probably has a big role in the cause of primary hypertension.

title: Role of Sugar in Hypertension
content: In the process of developing high blood pressure there are 2 players: the initiators and the things that make it persistent. The inflammation in the kidney is involved in the persistence. In the initiation, turns out that sugar has a major role.

title: Fructose, Glucose, and Sugar
content: The different types of sugar: Glucose is the primary sugar that our body uses to make energy. When that’s too high we call it diabetes. When the blood glucose is too low, it’s hypoglycemia. Fructose is a natural sugar found in fruit. Fructose is the sugar that is involved in energy storage rather than energy production. Table sugar (aka sucrose) = glucose + fructose at 50/50 ratio. High fructose corn syrup = typically 55% fructose, 45% glucose in soft drinks.

title: Ancient Mutation in Apes and Fat Storage
content: An ancient mutation in apes that explains why humans turn fructose into fat so easily. A small subset of them developed a mutation in uric acid metabolism that gave them a superpower. That superpower was that they could be much more efficient at turning fructose into fat.

title: Elevated Uric Acid Levels and Health Problems
content: The problems with elevated uric acid levels, and what it tells us about how sugar causes disease. The classic story told is that human’s get gout because of too much uric acid. And we increase our uric acid by eating too much meat and protein. But the story is more nuanced. Gout is also increased by sugar.

title: Uric Acid and High Blood Pressure
content: The effect of uric acid on blood pressure. Some epidemiologic studies linked uric acid with high blood pressure. People with gout often have low grade kidney disease. So the thought was, “Maybe uric acid could have a role in causing kidney disease through causing high blood pressure through its ability to cause kidney disease”.

title: How Sugar Causes Obesity
content: How sugar causes obesity—explaining the difference in glucose vs. fructose metabolism and the critical pathway induced by fructose. Although they look alike, the metabolism of fructose is extremely different from the metabolism of glucose. When fructose is metabolized, there’s this process that causes the energy in the cell to fall before it goes up. Fructose turns out to be used by animals as a mechanism to store fat.

title: AMPK vs. AMPD Pathway
content: Further explaining the AMPK vs. AMPD pathway. The pathway discussed below is a big part of Rick’s book, The Fat Switch. Adenosine triphosphate = ATP. The liberation of a phosphate is the production of energy. That liberation create adenosine diphosphate (ADP). Another phosphate can be donated to the production of energy which creates adenosine monophosphate (AMP). This is where there is a “fork” in the road…

title: Insulin Resistance and Diabetes
content: Stimulating AMPK can be used to treat diabetes. The switch towards AMPD is the fallen intracellular phosphate. The reason that phosphate falls is because it’s taken up by fructose. The fructose gets phosphorylated by the ATP and it becomes fructose one phosphate that sequesters phosphate. This is the process where both ATP levels fall and intracellular phosphate falls and that triggers this AMPD pathway. If you interrupt the AMPD pathway, you can block a lot of the metabolic effects.

title: Uric Acid and Metabolic Effects
content: Part of the pathway through which AMPD is working involves the generation of uric acid. When the uric acid is going up inside the cell it’s doing all kinds of biologic effects and the AMPD is driving that.

title: Sugar Consumption and Obesity
content: Drinking sugar is much more likely to cause problems compared to eating sugar. The reason is that when you drink a drink that has fructose in it, we tend to drink a lot in a short period of time. And when fructose gets to the liver, it’s the concentration that triggers this reaction. If the concentration of fructose is really low, the ATP depletion may not be significant to drive dramatic metabolic effects.

title: Fructose and Metabolic Syndrome
content: Signs of metabolic syndrome include: Elevated blood sugar, Elevated blood pressure, Elevated waist circumference, Elevated triglycerides, And low HDL. Fructose does all five. Fructose also generates a lot of lactate. Fructose also preferentially decreases mitochondrial function and stimulates glycolysis. All those things cause big oxidative stress to the mitochondria.

title: Uric Acid's Effect on the Pancreas
content: The generation uric acid is also causing oxidative stress to the pancreatic islets. Over time, the rats serum insulin levels began to fall, resembling type 1 diabetes. This is just like humans do.

title: Fructose and Cancer
content: For cancer cells, fructose can be an incredible survival nutrient in the setting of near starvation. Many cancers (colon, liver, kidney, breast, brain, all these cancer cells, intestinal) tend to like fructose as their preferential fuel.

title: Fructose and Lactate
content: The more fructose given to a cell, the more lactate will increase. About 20% of fructose is used by the intestine, Maybe 40% by the liver, and At least 10 to 20% can escape into the circulation and cause problems to the kidney for example (The larger the dose, the more that will escape).

title: Fructokinase Inhibitors
content: There are fructokinase inhibitors that are being developed by Pfizer. It was quite successful at treating fatty liver and so now they’re taking that drug to phase three.

title: Treating High Uric Acid Levels
content: If patients have high uric acid levels but are not yet experiencing gout, it is typically lowered with allopurinol. It may improve insulin sensitivity, benefit kidney disease, and improve blood pressure.

title: Salt and Blood Pressure
content: Salt does play a role in blood pressure. However, it’s not just about the total amount of salt. It’s the combination of salt and water. You want to avoid an increase in serum sodium and you can reduce that by drinking water before eating a salty meal. When you eat salt, you’re making fructose in your body which is then driving a lot of effects.

title: Salt, Obesity and Diabetes
content: High salt diets are associated with obesity and the development of diabetes. High salt looks like it works by producing fructose.

title: Salt and Kidney Disease
content: People with kidney disease have to be more conscious of reducing salt consumption. However, increased water intake may slow the progression of kidney disease.

title: Drinking Water and Weight Management
content: Many animals use fructose to make fat as a means for making water. When you make fat, although there’s no water stored in the fat, when you burn the fat, it makes water. Fructose drives fat production in part to preserve water (not just energy). If you take an animal that’s consuming high fructose, you can suppress some of the obesity and metabolic syndrome by giving it a lot of water.

title: Reducing Fructose Intake
content: If we could reduce our fructose intake, it would have a huge effect. Unfortunately, this is easier said than done because sugar and high fructose corn syrup are in almost everything, especially processed foods.

title: Glucose-to-Fructose Conversion
content: If you give high amounts of glucose to an animal, as the glucose hits the liver it induces an enzyme called aldose reductase which converts glucose to fructose. When feeding mice high glucose it can convert to fructose endogenously. When they blocked their fructose metabolism, even though they’re eating the same amount of glucose, they’re not getting as fat, they have no fatty liver, they’re not insulin resistant.

title: Artificial Sweeteners vs. Real Sugar
content: Artificial sugar is driven by the sweet taste but what makes animals like real sugar is through its metabolism. If you give a mouse artificial sugar, they don’t gain weight. But if you give them regular sugar, they do.

title: Umami, MSG, Alcohol, Beer and Metabolic Illness
content: Umami is driven by glutamate but it’s markedly enhanced by purines like IMP and even uric acid. Umami is sort of a taste receptor for uric acid type foods. MSG is the primary stimulant and people put it in foods to encourage food intake. Some link of umami with obesity in epidemiologic studies. Some situations where you can induce obesity with umami (especially in liquid form).

title: Fructose Consumption
content: In the form of fruit juices, sports drinks, and sodas, liquid sugar should be avoided. However, patients on a low fructose diet, that then added in a single fruit to their diet, did just as good as the no fruit group. Some low fructose fruits include kiwi, lime, lemon, blueberries, raspberries, strawberries. In contrast, grapes have a lot of sugar.

title: Recommended Fructose Intake
content: For patients that have a non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, it is recommended to restrict them to 10 grams a day of fructose, only in the form of whole fruit. This means no grapes, no bananas, no large apples, etc.

title: Managing Children's Sugar Intake
content: It is important to manage the sugar intake of children. This can be done by allowing them to have treats on special occasions, substituting some sugar for alternatives like splenda when baking at home, and avoiding fruit juice or regular soft drinks. It is also important to educate them about the role of sugar in obesity and diabetes, and the importance of understanding food labels.

title: Dried Fruit and Health
content: Dried fruit is the fructose of fruits without the beneficial components. It is essentially pure fructose.
